title: Explain acceleration of X and Y

content.question: Two charged particles, <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, are placed near each other and released from rest. Particle <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> has twice the mass and twice the charge that particle <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> has. Which of the following best explains why the acceleration of particle <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is half that of particle <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

choices.label: The particles exert forces on each other that have the same magnitude. The mass of particle <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is twice that of particle <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, so the acceleration of particle <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is half that of particle <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.

The particles exert forces on each other that have the same magnitude. The electric charge of particle <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is twice that of particle <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, so particle <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> exerts an electric force on particle <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> that is twice as great as the electric force particle <math alttext="X" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> exerts on particle <math alttext="Y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>Y</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>.
